info.description:
hcoe is a Hyper Converged Management system from HPE.

This document provides the API reference for all the APIs exposed by hcoe.
info.title: hcoe API.

get.description: Query and filter images.
get.summary: Query and filter images.

parameters.description:
Integer indicating the index of the member that the collection response representation will begin with,
where '0' represents the first available resource (i.e., zero-based index).
parameters.name: start

parameters.description: Integer indicating the number of collection members to include in the response. The minimum value for this parameter is 1.
parameters.name: count

parameters.description:
view=summary: When the 'summary' view is applied to an individual resource URI, the response will include the name, type, version and uri.
When the 'summary' view is applied to a collection, the response contains the collection attributes,
including the number of members if available, but does not return the actual members.

view=condense: When the 'condense' view is applied to an individual resource URI, the response will only include the name, type and URI of the resource.
When 'condense' view is applied to a collection, the response contains the collection attributes, as well as the members.
However, only the name, type, and uri attributes of the members of the collection are included in the response.
parameters.name: view

parameters.description:
Comma separated list of attribute names indicating which attributes to return in the response.
If an attribute is not present in the resource, then it will be ignored.
parameters.name: fields

post.description:
Create a VM with the given inputs.

Initiates the create VM task with the given inputs and returns
the task URI. (See the response body.) The URI can be used to track
the status of the task by connecting to the websocket of the
hcoe server at that task URI endpoint.
post.summary: Create a VM with the given inputs.

parameters.description:
Virtual Machine Profile to use during VM Creation.
If this field is specified, only the name and the servercount fields will be honored.
All other inputs will be discarded, and the inputs specified in the given profile will be used.
parameters.name: vmProfileId

parameters.description: Workspace UUID the vm will belong to when being created.
parameters.name: workspaceId

parameters.description: Resource pool to create the VM from.
parameters.name: vmresourcepool

parameters.description: Amount of RAM to be provisioned for the VM.
parameters.name: memorySizeMB

parameters.description: Size of the boot disk to be provisioned for the VM.
parameters.name: diskSizeMB

parameters.description: Operating system.
parameters.name: os

parameters.description: Name of the VM. In the case of bulk create, this is the prefix to be used.
parameters.name: name

parameters.description: Bootable image to use for this VM.
parameters.name: bootableImageId

parameters.description: Number of virtual machines to be created (default 1)
parameters.name: servercount

parameters.description: List of actions to execute on the VM post the VM creation. The actions will be executed in the order specified and sequentially.
parameters.name: postActions

parameters.description: vmfolder to create the VM in.
parameters.name: vmfolder

parameters.description: Custom specification image to use for this VM. (Not implemented yet. Placeholder).
parameters.name: customSpecificationImageId

parameters.description: Number of CPUs to be provisioned for the VM
parameters.name: cpuCount

parameters.description: Any custom attributes relevant for the VM.
parameters.name: vmCustomSpecification

post.description:
Migrates VMs to different Hosts. The destination Hosts could also be in a different Cluster.
If the movement is within the same cluster, Live Migration will be done for running VMs, meaning no shutdown will be required.

post.description: Execute specific action name. Allowed values are start, stop, restart, suspend and delete.

parameters.description: Identifiers of the virtual machines on which the management operation is to be performed.
parameters.name: ids

post.description:
Clients can stop subscribing to utilization metrics updates on a perviously connected the websocket endpoint
GET /hcoe/virtual-machines/metrics-subscriptions/{subscriptionUUID}.

Returns utilization metrics (See the response body) along with a metrics websocket URI.
Websocket URI is of the form GET /hcoe/virtual-machines/metrics-subscriptions/{subscriptionUUID}.
Clients can get utilization metrics updates by connecting to the websocket and listening for updates.
Response body also includes a stop monitoring request URI to stop the subscription to metrics update
when client no longer needs the metrics updates on the subscription. The stop monitoring request URI
is of the form POST /rest/virtual-machines/metrics-subscriptions/{subscriptionUUID}/stop.

Edit a VM with the given inputs.

the edit operation.

get.description:
Clients can subscribe to this websocket endpoint. The task ID is given as part of the URI.
This subscriptions provide the real-time live feed on the task status.
An earlier asynchronous request made by the client provided them with the task URI.
get.summary: Get the real-time live feed on the task status for the requested task id on the websocket endpoint.

get.description:
Clients can connect to this websocket endpoint and receive live metrics updates. The subscription ID is given as part of the URI.
An earlier request made by the client provided them with the subscription UUID and URI.
get.summary: Get the update on monitored VM utilization metrics

get.description: Displays the welcome message.
get.summary: Displays the welcome message.

DB.description:
The sql package creates and frees connections automatically; it
also maintains a free pool of idle connections. If the database has
a concept of per-connection state, such state can only be reliably
observed within a transaction. Once DB.Begin is called, the
returned Tx is bound to a single connection. Once Commit or
Rollback is called on the transaction, that transaction's
connection is returned to DB's idle connection pool. The pool size
can be controlled with SetMaxIdleConns.
DB.title:
DB is a database handle representing a pool of zero or more
underlying connections. It's safe for concurrent use by multiple
goroutines.

OpenConnections.description: OpenConnections is the number of open connections to the database.

Duration.description:
A Duration represents the elapsed time between two instants
as an int64 nanosecond count.  The representation limits the
largest representable duration to approximately 290 years.

NullBool implements the Scanner interface so
it can be used as a scan destination, similar to NullString.

NullInt64 implements the Scanner interface so
it can be used as a scan destination, similar to NullString.
NullInt64.title: NullInt64 represents an int64 that may be null.

NullString.title:
NullString represents a string that may be null.
NullString implements the Scanner interface so
it can be used as a scan destination:

RawBytes.description:
RawBytes is a byte slice that holds a reference to memory owned by
the database itself. After a Scan into a RawBytes, the slice is only
valid until the next call to Next, Scan, or Close.

ids.description:
List of virtual machine Ids to be renamed.
in:body

Result.title: A Result summarizes an executed SQL command.

Row.title: Row is the result of calling QueryRow to select a single row.

Rows.description:
rows, err := db.Query("SELECT ...")
...
defer rows.Close()
for rows.Next() {
var id int
var name string
err = rows.Scan(&id, &name)
...
}
err = rows.Err() // get any error encountered during iteration
...
Rows.title:
Rows is the result of a query. Its cursor starts before the first row
of the result set. Use Next to advance through the rows:

Scanner.title: Scanner is an interface used by Scan.

associatedResourceInstanceIds.description: Identifiers of the resource instances associated with this task.

associatedResourceInstanceNames.description: Names of the associated resource instances with this task.

associatedResourceInstanceUris.description: URIs of the associated resource instances with this task.

associatedResourceType.description: Resource type associated with this task. Examples: virtual-machines.

error.description: Error structure that captures the error details of the task. Applies only when the TaskFailed is true.

isPartialSuccess.description: Indicates if the task succeed partially. Applies only when the TaskFailed is false.

status.description: Cumulative status of task computed from status of all associated instances

taskFailed.description: Indicates if the task has failed overall.

taskResults.description: List of task results from this task. Applies only when the task status is terminal.

terminalState.description: Indicates if the task state given in this structure is terminal.

errorCode.description: Error code that indicates the overall task failure.

errorDetails.description: Error details that explain the overall task failure.

errorMessage.description: Error message that explains the overall task failure.

errorCode.description: Indicates the error code on why this particular resource instance operation failed. Applies when Failed is true.

errorMessage.description: Indicates the error message on why this particular resource instance operation failed. Applies when Failed is true.

failed.description: Indicates if this particular resource instance operation failed.

resultingResourceInstanceId.description: Resource instance id that has resulted as a part of this task result.

resultingResourceInstanceName.description: Resource instance name that has resulted as a part of this task result.

resultingResourceInstanceStatus.description: Status of Resource instance that has resulted as a part of this task result.

resultingResourceInstanceType.description: Tesource instance type that has resulted as a part of this task result.

resultingResourceInstanceUri.description: Resource instance uri that has resulted as a part of this task result.

Time.description:
Programs using times should typically store and pass them as values,
not pointers.  That is, time variables and struct fields should be of
type time.Time, not *time.Time.  A Time value can be used by
multiple goroutines simultaneously.

Time instants can be compared using the Before, After, and Equal methods.
The Sub method subtracts two instants, producing a Duration.
The Add method adds a Time and a Duration, producing a Time.

The zero value of type Time is January 1, year 1, 00:00:00.000000000 UTC.
As this time is unlikely to come up in practice, the IsZero method gives
a simple way of detecting a time that has not been initialized explicitly.

Each Time has associated with it a Location, consulted when computing the
presentation form of the time, such as in the Format, Hour, and Year methods.
The methods Local, UTC, and In return a Time with a specific location.
Changing the location in this way changes only the presentation; it does not
change the instant in time being denoted and therefore does not affect the
computations described in earlier paragraphs.

Note that the Go == operator compares not just the time instant but also the
Location. Therefore, Time values should not be used as map or database keys
without first guaranteeing that the identical Location has been set for all
values, which can be achieved through use of the UTC or Local method.
Time.title: A Time represents an instant in time with nanosecond precision.

Tx.description:
A transaction must end with a call to Commit or Rollback.

After a call to Commit or Rollback, all operations on the
transaction fail with ErrTxDone.

The statements prepared for a transaction by calling
the transaction's Prepare or Stmt methods are closed
by the call to Commit or Rollback.
Tx.title: Tx is an in-progress database transaction.

UpdateWorkspaceParameters.title: Inputs that can be sent when Updating a workspace.

memorySizeGB.description: Amount of RAM to be provisioned for the VM.

modifiedTime.description: Time at which the Profile was modified.

Weekday.title: A Weekday specifies a day of the week (Sunday = 0, ...).

WelcomeMessage.title: Welcome Message for HPE hcoe Hyper Converged System.

connRequest.description:
connRequest represents one request for a new connection
When there are no idle connections available, DB.conn will create
a new connRequest and put it on the db.connRequests list.

connReuseStrategy.title: connReuseStrategy determines how (*DB).conn returns database connections.

connStmt.title: connStmt is a prepared statement on a particular connection.

depSet.description: depSet is a finalCloser's outstanding dependencies

driverConn.description:
driverConn wraps a driver.Conn with a mutex, to
be held during all calls into the Conn. (including any calls onto
interfaces returned via that Conn, such as calls on Tx, Stmt,
Result, Rows)

driverStmt.description:
driverStmt associates a driver.Stmt with the
driverConn from which it came, so the driverConn's lock can be
held during calls.

finalCloser.description:
The finalCloser interface is used by (*DB).addDep and related
dependency reference counting.

finalClose.description:
finalClose is called when the reference count of an object
goes to zero. (*DB).mu is not held while calling it.
